title: Rebuilding the Temple
shortSummary: Ezra chapter 5 recounts the renewed efforts to rebuild the temple in Jerusalem under the leadership of Zerubbabel and Jeshua, encouraged by the prophets Haggai and Zechariah. The chapter also details the inquiry by Persian officials and the letter sent to King Darius, affirming the legitimacy of the work based on the decree of Cyrus.
timeline: c. 520 BC - Early Persian Period, during the reign of Darius I

keyCharacters.name: Zerubbabel
keyCharacters.description: Governor of Judah and descendant of King David, who leads the rebuilding of the temple.

keyCharacters.name: Jeshua
keyCharacters.description: High priest who partners with Zerubbabel in rebuilding the temple and restoring worship.

keyCharacters.name: Haggai
keyCharacters.description: Prophet who encourages the people to resume building the temple.

keyCharacters.name: Zechariah
keyCharacters.description: Prophet and son of Iddo, who also motivates the Jews to continue the temple construction.

keyCharacters.name: Tatnai
keyCharacters.description: Governor on the western side of the Euphrates River who questions the Jews about their building activities.

definitions.definition: A messenger chosen by God to deliver His word and encourage obedience among His people.

definitions.term: Governor on this side the river
definitions.definition: A Persian official overseeing the provinces west of the Euphrates River, including Judah.
The official authorization by King Cyrus permitting the Jews to return to Jerusalem and rebuild the temple.
The temple in Jerusalem, the central place of worship for the Israelites.
A group or officials associated with Tatnai and Shetharboznai, likely Persian administrators.

outline.heading: Prophetic Encouragement and Resumption of Work
outline.description: The prophets Haggai and Zechariah inspire the Jews in Judah and Jerusalem to rebuild the temple, leading Zerubbabel and Jeshua to begin construction with prophetic support.

outline.heading: Inquiry by Persian Officials
outline.description: Tatnai and Shetharboznai question the Jews about their authority to build the temple and walls, but God protects the elders so the work continues until the matter reaches King Darius.

outline.heading: Letter to King Darius
outline.description: The Persian officials send a letter to King Darius detailing the construction progress and requesting verification of the decree by Cyrus authorizing the temple rebuilding, affirming the Jews’ lawful actions.

application: Trust in God’s timing and prophetic guidance when undertaking difficult tasks, as the people did under Haggai and Zechariah.
Respond to opposition with integrity and patience, relying on God’s protection and providence as Zerubbabel and Jeshua did.
Seek to verify and honor God’s commands and promises, just as the Persian officials sought confirmation of Cyrus’s decree.
Commit to faithful obedience in rebuilding spiritual foundations, prioritizing God’s house and worship.

keyVerses.text: Then the prophets, Haggai the prophet, and Zechariah the son of Iddo, prophesied unto the Jews that were in Judah and Jerusalem in the name of the God of Israel, even unto them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the vital role of prophetic encouragement in renewing the people’s commitment to God’s work.

keyVerses.text: Then rose up Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel, and Jeshua the son of Jozadak, and began to build the house of God which is at Jerusalem: and with them were the prophets of God helping them.
keyVerses.significance: It shows the leadership and cooperation between civil and spiritual leaders in accomplishing God’s purposes.

keyVerses.text: But in the first year of Cyrus the king of Babylon the same king Cyrus made a decree to build this house of God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse confirms the divine authorization behind the rebuilding project, legitimizing the Jews’ efforts.

keyVerses.text: Now therefore, if it seem good to the king, let there be search made in the king's treasure house, which is there at Babylon, whether it be so, that a decree was made of Cyrus the king to build this house of God at Jerusalem, and let the king send his pleasure to us concerning this matter.
keyVerses.significance: It demonstrates the appeal to rightful authority and the importance of transparency and obedience to governing powers.
